content.description: Follow slabs and rails up to a fairly large ledge. Two cold shut anchors are at the top.
content.location: This is just right of the three pitch route, Jungle Mountaineering. Lower from the two bolt anchors. You can get away with a 60m rope.

content.description: Climb over several bulges and a short headwall.
content.location:
This is just to the left of the first pitch of

Lost in the Jungle

.

content.description: The crux is moving through a roof. That is pretty much the business of this route.
content.protection: 8 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This is the fourth route from the left. There is a two bolt anchor at the top. A 60m rope will work.

content.description:
This is a three pitch moderate line up the right hand side of The Jungle formation.  The first pitch starts on the mellow slab and pulls a small roof about halfway up at a small, right-facing corner. 5.6, 7 bolts.

The second pitch starts above the belay and angles left over easy ground to a ledge below a crack in a steep wall.  This wide, arching crack is the crux. 5.9, 9 bolts.

The third pitch is short and heads up a slab on good holds.  When the angle eases off, a bolt anchor is found to the left. 5.7, 6 bolts.
content.protection: Bolts.  There are fixed anchors atop each pitch.
content.location:
This is the furthest right bolted line at The Jungle.  It starts downhill from the other routes near a large pine tree next to the slab.  To get down, walk off to the right or rappel.  If rappelling, descend to the second belay and then rappel

The Green Tornado

which is climber's left of Lost in the Jungle.  A single rope, even a 70m, is not long enough to rappel from the second anchors to those atop the first pitch.  Do not rappel the lower part of the route without two ropes.

content.description: The crux is off of the 3rd bolt moving through the roof on the first pitch. It never gets any harder.
content.protection: This is bolt protected. The 1st pitch has [11] bolts; pitch 2, 8 bolts; pitch 3, 12 bolts.
content.location:
This is the left most route at The Jungle (right now).  To the left of the route is a crack that seems to stays wet. To the right of this route is the route,

Welcome to The Jungle

.

content.description: The movement on the route is good. Kudos to the peeps who put up the routes on this wall. Start climbing a slab to a roof and follow steeper terrain to the anchors.
content.protection:
8 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor protect this route.

Per

Andy Keck

: there is a missing hanger!
content.location: The third route on this wall if you are counting them from left to right. 60m rope will get you back down.

content.description:
Climb up the slab to the steep wall above.  Move right to a weakness in black rock about 10' right of the crux on

Bungle in the Jungle

.  It is a little balancy getting established in the area of black rock.  From here, pull straight up to the slab above and the anchor.
content.protection: Bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is located just right of

Bungle in the Jungle

with which it shares an anchor.

content.description:
P1. This is the 5th route from the left on the main wall. The first 40' is 5.2 slab, but then you get a slightly tricky roof pull (.10b). That is followed by a 10' fist crack then some 5.9 stuff to the anchors. If your belayer stands on the dirt and lowers you all the way, you'll use 100% of a 60m rope, so be careful, 5.10, 99'. The slab is low angle here though, so an accident would mostly be hilarious for whoever saw it.

Per

Mike Carrington

: the second pitch is around 5.8, and the third is maybe 5.9.  These go up the orange headwall.
content.protection: 9 bolts plus clips for the chains. You could bring along one 3" piece of gear for the short crack, or just clip the bolt. There was not enough of the crack to warrant a mixed line.
content.location: 5th route down from the North on the main face.

content.description: This fine little climb ascends a low angle slab to a steep wall with amazing holds.  This wall is just right of a right-facing dihedral with a big bush in it.  The crux is the upper part of the steep wall.  You have to move quick here to avoid getting pumped out.  After pulling onto the slab above the steep section, move right to the anchor.
content.protection:
Bolts to an anchor shared with the route to the right,

The Green Tornado

.
content.location:
This starts about 30' right of

The Cougar Wisperer

on a low angle slab.  Descend from a two bolt anchor.

content.description: This is the farthest left route. Start far left and angle up to the right following the slab up and right to the roof. Pull the roof to easy climbing and the anchors.
